docs.lead_paragraph: FOR her wedding last year before 100 guests at the historic Mission Inn in Riverside, Calif., Neomi Padilla, 32, wore a sexy spaghetti-strap dress from L'ezu Atelier in Newport Beach and four-inch heels. Then she held on for dear life.
docs.abstract: Brides are growing less shy about walking down the aisle visibly pregnant; dress designers are responding by increasing their options for expecting mothers; photos (M)
docs.snippet: These days, women planning simultaneously for a wedding and a due date are showing off their pregnancies.

docs.lead_paragraph: A FEW weeks ago, in response to the musings of Harvard's president, Lawrence H. Summers, on women and science, I wrote about the need to reimagine the workplace. Women are in fact different from men, I said, not in their abilities, but in the timing, and breadth, of their parental responsibilities. Careers, therefore, should allow for stopping and starting, leaving and re-entering. This column is also a response -- to the many of you who wrote to ask how to make such change happen. What exactly, you asked, should such a redefined workplace look like? Give us specifics, you said. Show us programs.

headline.main: Goodbye Doesn't Need to Mean Forever

docs.abstract: Life's Work column responds to reader requests for information about companies that are experimenting with programs that have retention programs for women and offer flexibility to women with families; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: What does a workplace that is redesigned to suit the needs of women who need to stop and start, leave and re-enter look like?

docs.lead_paragraph: Andrea Echeverri When Andrea Echeverri sings about her baby, as she does throughout her self-titled album (Nacional), she doesn't mean her lover. Ms. Echeverri, the singer from the Colombian band Aterciopelados, wrote the songs during her pregnancy and after the birth of her daughter, Milagros. The music has the sly lilt and electronic fringes of the Latin lounge-pop she sings with Aterciopelados, while the lyrics, in Spanish, are filled with maternal love, wonderment and unabashed observations of the changes in her own body. ''Ya Yo No'' marvels that ''I'' has changed to ''we''; ''A Eme O'' celebrates her reawakened lust; and ''Lactochampeta'' -- amid chirps and whistles -- savors nursing: ''Satisfy all your appetites with me, baby.'' Rarely has motherhood sounded so blithe or so sexy. Earth From 1992 to 1996, a Seattle band called Earth released five albums of droning, sludgy, largely instrumental rock that was something like grunge's slowed-down answer to Sonic Youth; it was also a precursor to bands from Kyuss to Sigur Ros. Among their relatively few fans were musicians, and ''Legacy of Dissolution'' (No Quarter) set loose some of them to remix Earth songs. Mogwai remakes ''Teeth of Lions Rule the Divine'' with new electronics flickering and looping around Earth's tolling guitars; Jim O'Rourke savors the minimalistic sustain of ''Thrones and Dominions.'' All six remixers are surprisingly reverent about the originals, which, indeed, are hard to top. But they should draw attention to an album that Earth's founder, Dylan Carlson, plans to start recording next month. The Kills Rock duos have lost their novelty lately, but they haven't stopped making lean, memorable music. The Kills' new album, ''No Wow'' (Rough Trade) is nearly as stripped down as its title. VV ( aka Alison Mosshart), who sings and plays guitar, and Hotel (Jamie Hince), who sings backup and plays guitar, bass and drums, do allow themselves some overdubs and drum-machine assistance. Yet they keep the songs pithy, putting two or three frazzled chords behind instant mottos like ''I hate the way you love.'' For all that the Kills owe to P.J. Harvey, they also have angles of their own. El Pus Rap-rock makes a sidelong comeback by way of this Atlanta band, which is pronounced El POOSE, but, luckily, has few other pretensions. It's not the self-pitying rap-rock of late-1990's metal bands. El Pus's songs on the album ''Hoodlum Rock: Vol. 1'' (Virgin) are closer to punk-pop and the rock forays of OutKast and N.E.R.D. They have a sense of humor that applies equally to would-be thugs and their own sexual conquests or lack thereof. Rare is the rapper -- or rocker -- who'd set out to pick up women with Radiohead's '''Kid A' in the beatbox,'' or admit it afterward. Heartless Bastards When Erika Wennerstrom announces ''I'm gonna take everything, everything!'' on the Heartless Bastards' debut album ''Stairs and Elevators'' (Fat Possum), the raw quaver in her untamed voice gives her as much bite as the distortion on her guitar. Bravado runs through her songs, which drag midtempo British rock -- from the Kinks to Bowie to Oasis -- into a grimy American garage. Between her constant fuzz-tone and her burly two-man rhythm section, the album as a whole grows one-dimensional. But before it does, Ms. Wennerstrom leaves a vivid impression. Sam Prekop Seconds into the first track of Sam Prekop's album ''Who's Your New Professor'' (Thrill Jockey), folky guitar picking is enveloped in burbling synthesizer and rustling jazz drums. That mutability of styles runs through this quietly ambitious album. Mr. Prekop is a decidedly modest singer, which makes him right for lyrics full of uncertainties and could-have-beens: ''Gotta know for sure, don't I?'' His songs ruminate amid folk and bossa nova, hovering guitar patterns and hazy jazz trumpets. They're amiable and elusive, drifting at will. Jack Johnson Recorded mostly with just acoustic guitar, bass, drums and Jack Johnson's breathy voice, the songs on ''In Between Dreams'' (Universal) are so light and self-effacing they might scatter in a tropical breeze. As Mr. Johnson vamps pleasantly, he tries to ponder mortality and ethics along with romance, aiming for something as intimate as Nick Drake minus the inner torment. But without the torment, well . . . here comes that breeze. --
docs.abstract: John Pareles reviews new recordings by Andrea Echeverri, Earth, The Kills, El Pus, Heartless Bastards, Sam Prekop and Jack Johnson; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Andrea Echeverri sings about motherhood in her first solo album; also, Sam Prekop, El Pus, Earth, the Kills and more.

docs.lead_paragraph: Women in New York City are more likely to be obese and less likely to exercise than men, which increases their risk of heart disease, diabetes and other ailments that can cut lives short, according to a report to be issued today by the city's Health Department. The report, ''Women at Risk: The Health of Women in New York City,'' focused on an array of issues affecting women's health, including access to health care and cancer screenings as well as behavioral issues, and was based on data pertaining specifically to women that was culled from several surveys in 2002 and 2003.

headline.main: Study Finds More Obesity and Less Exercising Among New York City's Women Than Its Men

docs.abstract: New York City Health Department study finds that women in New York City are more likely to be obese and less likely to exercise than men; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Women in New York City are more likely to be obese and less likely to exercise than men, which increases their risk of heart disease, diabetes and other ailments that can cut lives short, according to a report to be issued today by the city's Health...

docs.lead_paragraph: Regard the colicky baby at full throttle. Tiny arms and legs stiffen. Tummy goes hard. Face resembles a beet emitting paroxysmal shrieks. Unbelievably, the cry goes on for one, two, even three hours without pause. What's a parent to do? Run a checklist. Is the baby hungry? Wet? Feeling gas pains? Allergic to something?

headline.main: Colicky Baby? Read This Before Calling an Exorcist

docs.abstract: Pediatricians and medical experts disagree about what causes colic, inconsolable crying, in infants, and how to deal with it; some feel babies are not in pain, but are experiencing normal growth and emotional changes that accompany birth; others feel it is brought on by underlying medical condition; pediatrician Dr Harvey Karp, who is author of The Happiest Baby on the Block, says there are five steps that performed in order will trigger calming instinct in baby and stop colic; his theory discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Researchers and doctors are offering plentiful (if sometimes contradictory) advice on calming screaming babies.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: HAPPIEST BABY ON THE BLOCK, THE (BOOK)

docs.lead_paragraph: The last time Jane Fonda was in the news, a little over a year ago, a doctored photograph placed her next to John Kerry at a 1970's antiwar rally she hadn't even attended -- a trick meant to hurt Mr. Kerry's presidential chances by linking him to the woman nicknamed Hanoi Jane. But just a month later a poll by the nonpartisan Annenberg Public Policy Center turned up some startling results. Asked to identify people mentioned during the campaign, 40 percent of the respondents thought of Ms. Fonda as an actress and only 20 percent as an antiwar activist. So much for her status as political poison. And that softer image was no fluke. Less than two weeks ago, a poll measuring celebrities' appeal and recognition found that 62 percent actually liked Ms. Fonda, in varying degrees, while only 38 percent disliked her in some way. The survey, by E-Poll Market Research, also found that many more people recognized her name than her face, a strange result for a movie star.

headline.main: Where's Jane Fonda? On Yet Another Journey

docs.abstract: Caryn James Critic's Notebook column on actress and political activist Jane Fonda, who is making comeback with new autobiography, My Life So Far, and role in movie comedy, Monster-in-Law; while she has not made movie in 15 years, her influence on popular culture, from Vietnam War-era antiwar protests to workout videos in 1980's, has been enormous; photos (M)
docs.snippet: At 67, Jane Fonda is making a comeback with an autobiography and, yes, a film with Jennifer Lopez.
